data.title: Canadian international de Guzman sporting director, unveil assistant coaches
data.meta_description: The Red Bulls filled out their technical staff on Friday.
data.text:
HARRISON, N.J. – The Red Bulls filled out their technical staff on Friday.

They named former Canadian international Julian de Guzman as sporting director. He succeeds Denis Hamlett, who parted way with the club last year.

The MLS club also announced that Volkan Bulut, Vedad Ibisevic and Ibrahim Sekagya will serve as assistant coaches under head coach Sandro Schwarz.

Julian de Guzman

De Guzman, 42, was a founder, managing partner, and president of Simcoe Rovers County FC, which plays in League1 Ontario. Before that< de Guzman was general Manager of Ottawa Fury Football Club, where he managed the day-to-day operations of the sporting department and helped guide Ottawa to a USL Championship playoff appearance in 2019. He was also the Head Coach of Ottawa Fury during the 2017 season.

“Julian brings a wealth of experience, not only in our league, but also from abroad,” head of sport Jochen Schneider said in a statement. “His focus on our coaching staff, our players, our second team and our academy will help propel us forward.

“Julian has always been a leader, on- and off-the-pitch. His experience will be invaluable to our organization.”

The Toronto, Ontario native enjoyed a 19-year playing career, which began with Olympique de Marseille’s youth and reserve program. After he signed his first professional contract with 1. FC Saarbrücken in German 2. Bundesliga, de Guzman joined Hannover 96 under head coach Ralf Rangnick in 2002 and became the third Canadian to compete in the Bundesliga. De Guzman played 84 matches for Hanover before he made the move to Deportivo La Coruna in Spain’s La Liga. He was the first Canadian to play in that league and helped the club avoid in relegation during the 2007-08 season and gained a spot in the UEFA Cup. De Guzman also was named the team’s player of the season.

De Guzman joined Toronto FC in 2009 as a Designated Player, becoming the first Canadian DP in league history. He made 93 appearances for Toronto, recording three goals and seven assists. He is the second-leading Canadian in Concacaf Champions League appearances with 18. He won the Canadian Championship with Toronto FC in 2010, 2011, and 2012.

In 2012, he was traded to FC Dallas and made 12 appearances for the club. De Guzman had other stints with Jahn Regensburg and Skoda Xanthi FC. He finished his playing career with Ottawa Fury FC, where he was the club captain and also during his last season in 2016, he was the Ottawa Fury reserve team coach.

“I am proud and honored to be a part of this renowned organization,” de Guzman said in a statement. “The New York Red Bulls have been an exemplary model of soccer in North America, and I am very motivated to achieve great things with this team. I can’t wait to be a part of the family.”

De Guzman played 17 years in the Canadian national team system, including 14 years with the senior side. He made his debut for the senior team in a 2002 Concacaf Gold Cup match against Martinique. He was named to six Gold Cup teams, earned the 2007 Gold Cup tournament MVP and was selected to the Concacaf Gold Cup All-Tournament team in 2007 and 2009. De Guzman was voted the Canadian MNT player of the year in 2008 and is the second all-time caps leader for Canada with 89 appearances. He started 25 games as Canada captain.

Assistant coaches

Volkan Bulut, Vedad Ibiševic, and Ibrahim Sekagya will serve as assistant coaches.

Jeremy Proud will continue to serve as goalkeeper coach. Dominik Wohlert will continue to serve as the head of performance analysis and will have an on-field role as well. Daniel Fischer will join head coach Sandro Schwarz’s staff as senior performance analyst.

Sekagya also will continue to be the head coach of Red Bulls II.

Bulut and Ibiševic will join the club, pending the receipt of their work visas.

Bulut, 41, was a member Schwarz’s staff after working under him during his stints at Dynamo Moscow and Hertha Berlin. He brings 11 years of experience as an assistant coach. Bulut also has coached at TSV Havelse, SC Paderborn, FC Schalke 04, and Hannover 96. He had a 10-year playing career where he played for TuS Celle FC, SC Langenhagen, VfV Hildesheim, and FC Can Mozaik.

Ibisevic, 39, served as an assistant coach with Hertha Berlin since 2022 atthe beginning of his coaching career. He played at Saint Louis University in 2003, where he was named one of the Top 25 recruits in the nation. He played professionally for Paris Saint-Germain, Alemannia Aachen, 1899 Hoffenheim, VfB Stuttgart, Hertha Berlin and Schalke 04. Ibisevic played internationally for Bosnia and Herzegovina, where made 83 appearances and scored 28 goals. He participated in Bosnia’s first World Cup appearance in 2014, where he scored the country’s first goal in World Cup history against Argentina.

Sekagya, 43, will serve Red Bulls II for his third season, while taking on assistant coach duties for the Red Bulls. In his first full season at the helm, Sekagya guided NYRB II to the Eastern Conference semifinals in its first season in MLS NEXT Pro, the club had a 14-8-6 record and finished fourth place in the Eastern Conference. Sekagya served as an assistant coach for NYRB II since the team’s inaugural season in 2015. The Kampala, Uganda native played for the Red Bulls for two seasons in 2013 and 2014, where he made 41 appearances across all competitions and was a member of the 2013 Supporters Shield winning team. He also played for Red Bull Salzburg from 2007 to 2013, making 225 appearances.
